commands.name: Step 1: Create Namespace
commands.command: kubectl create namespace scenarios --dry-run=client -o yaml | kubectl apply -f -

commands.name: Step 2: Create RBAC Resources
commands.description: Create ServiceAccount, Role, RoleBinding, and test pod
commands.explanation: Creates: ServiceAccount (rbac-demo-sa) for pod identity, Role (rbac-demo-role) with specific permissions, RoleBinding (rbac-demo-binding) connecting SA to Role, and test deployment using the SA.
commands.what_it_does: Creates ServiceAccount, Role, RoleBinding, and rbac-demo-app deployment.

commands.name: Step 3: Check ServiceAccount
commands.command: kubectl get serviceaccount rbac-demo-sa -n scenarios -o yaml
commands.explanation: Shows the ServiceAccount with automatically created token secret. Pods using this SA can authenticate to Kubernetes API with these credentials.

commands.name: Step 4: Check Role Permissions
commands.command: kubectl get role rbac-demo-role -n scenarios -o yaml
commands.explanation: Shows rules: apiGroups, resources (pods, services, deployments), and verbs (get, list, watch). This Role allows read-only access to pods, services, and deployments in scenarios namespace.
commands.what_it_does: Displays Role rules defining allowed operations.

commands.name: Step 5: Check RoleBinding
commands.command: kubectl get rolebinding rbac-demo-binding -n scenarios -o yaml
commands.description: View RoleBinding connecting SA to Role
commands.explanation: Shows subjects (rbac-demo-sa ServiceAccount) and roleRef (rbac-demo-role). This grants rbac-demo-sa the permissions defined in rbac-demo-role.
commands.what_it_does: Displays RoleBinding connecting ServiceAccount to Role.
commands.next_step: Test permissions with kubectl auth can-i.

commands.name: Step 6: Test List Pods Permission
commands.command: kubectl auth can-i list pods --as=system:serviceaccount:scenarios:rbac-demo-sa -n scenarios
commands.description: Check if ServiceAccount can list pods (should return 'yes')
commands.explanation: Tests whether rbac-demo-sa has permission to list pods. Should return 'yes' because rbac-demo-role includes 'list' verb for pods resource.
commands.what_it_does: Tests permission without actually performing the action.

commands.name: Step 7: Test Create Pods Permission
commands.command: kubectl auth can-i create pods --as=system:serviceaccount:scenarios:rbac-demo-sa -n scenarios
commands.description: Check if ServiceAccount can create pods (should return 'no')
commands.explanation: Should return 'no' because rbac-demo-role only allows get/list/watch, not create. This demonstrates principle of least privilege.

commands.name: Step 8: Exec into Test Pod
commands.description: Get shell in pod using rbac-demo-sa (type 'exit' when done)
commands.explanation: Opens shell in pod running with rbac-demo-sa ServiceAccount. From here, you can test API access using the SA's credentials. The pod has kubectl pre-installed for testing.
commands.next_step: Inside pod, run: kubectl get pods

commands.name: Step 9: Test API Access from Pod
commands.command: # Run inside pod: kubectl get pods -n scenarios
commands.description: (Run this inside pod from Step 8) Should succeed
commands.explanation: From inside the pod, this uses rbac-demo-sa credentials to list pods. Should work because rbac-demo-role allows 'list pods'. This demonstrates how pods can interact with Kubernetes API.
commands.what_it_does: Tests ServiceAccount permissions from within a pod.

commands.name: Step 10: Test Denied Action from Pod
commands.command: # Run inside pod: kubectl run test --image=nginx -n scenarios
commands.description: (Run this inside pod from Step 8) Should fail with 'forbidden'
commands.explanation: Attempts to create pod using rbac-demo-sa. Should fail with 'pods is forbidden: User ... cannot create resource'. Proves RBAC is enforcing permissions. Type 'exit' to leave pod shell.
commands.what_it_does: Tests that unauthorized actions are blocked.

commands.name: Summary: What You Learned
commands.description: Review all RBAC resources created in this scenario
commands.explanation: This command displays all ServiceAccounts, Roles, and RoleBindings in the scenarios namespace, giving you a complete view of the RBAC configuration you set up.
commands.what_it_does: Lists all RBAC resources for review and verification.

key_learnings: How to create ServiceAccounts for pod identity and authentication
How to define Roles with specific permissions (verbs, resources, apiGroups)
How to bind Roles to ServiceAccounts using RoleBindings
How to test permissions using kubectl auth can-i command
How to use ServiceAccounts in pod specifications
Understanding the principle of least privilege in Kubernetes RBAC
How to troubleshoot RBAC permissions from inside pods

commands_used.purpose: Create multiple Kubernetes resources from YAML manifests
View detailed ServiceAccount configuration and associated secrets
Inspect Role permissions including verbs and resources
View the binding between ServiceAccount and Role
Test if a ServiceAccount has specific permissions without executing the action
Open an interactive shell in a pod to test API access from within

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete RBAC Resources
commands.description: Remove all RBAC resources and test pod
commands.explanation: Deletes ServiceAccount, Role, RoleBinding, and deployment.
commands.what_it_does: Removes all RBAC resources created in this scenario.
